docs.abstract: Why was the father of microfinance dismissed from his bank in Bangladesh?
docs.snippet: Why was the father of microfinance dismissed from his bank in Bangladesh?
docs.lead_paragraph: Most Bangladeshis don’t have it so good. Their country, wedged between India and Burma, is wracked each year by flash floods. It is the third poorest nation in the world — trailing only Afghanistan and Angola. So you would think they might roll out the red carpet for their native son, Muhammad Yunus. The economist won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2006 and spawned a microfinance boomlet, with everyone from the Gates Foundation to smaller N.G.O.’s like Kiva piling on. But is he beloved in Bangladesh? Not so.

headline.main: Did ‘Hingsha’ Do In a Nobel Prize Winner?

docs.abstract: Countries situated in the likely path of melting glacial ice have more than many others to worry about as climate change makes the world warmer.
docs.snippet: Countries situated in the likely path of melting glacial ice have more than many others to worry about as climate change makes the world warmer.
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — With its massive chalk-white face of ice and snow, Thorthormi glacier in northern Bhutan looms high against a bright blue sky, nearly 4,450 meters above sea level. At the glacier’s base, a wide lake of murky water completes the dramatic scene at the rooftop of the world.

headline.main: Working in the Himalayas to Prevent Disastrous Flooding
headline.print_headline: Working in the Himalayas to Prevent Disastrous Flooding

docs.lead_paragraph: It’s time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

docs.abstract: To the residents of Bangkok neck-deep in floodwaters, the government’s inability to protect the city has come as a dirty surprise.
docs.snippet: To the residents of Bangkok neck-deep in floodwaters, the government’s inability to protect the city has come as a dirty surprise.
docs.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — In the industrial estate of Lat Krabang, a few kilometers from Bangkok’s international airport, Honda workers clad in ghost white are standing around the shuttered factory, like the idle employees of a suspended space program. The floodwaters are approaching from the north and the east, raising canal levels and bubbling up through drainage systems. One of the men says that the defenses — sandbags and plastic sheets — can withstand one meter of water, but no more.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

docs.abstract: Strong infrastructure can reduce risks, World Bank says.
docs.snippet: Strong infrastructure can reduce risks, World Bank says.
docs.lead_paragraph: The number of people exposed to natural disasters is expected to more than double to 1.5 billion by 2050, with 200 million of them in India, because of rapid urbanization and the extreme weather stemming from climate change, according to the World Bank.

headline.main: An Urbanizing India Faces Natural Disaster Risk

docs.abstract: Vulnerable countries press for climate aid as scientists summarize the complex forces shaping climate impacts
docs.snippet: Vulnerable countries press for climate aid as scientists summarize the complex forces shaping climate impacts
docs.lead_paragraph: This post is a tale of two climate conferences, and a forecast for a substantial risk of climate confusion later this week.

headline.main: Can Extreme Climate Confusion be Avoided?

docs.abstract: Aid workers worry that the drop in fleeing workers means more are trapped in Libya.
docs.snippet: Aid workers worry that the drop in fleeing workers means more are trapped in Libya.
docs.lead_paragraph: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  The flow of migrant workers fleeing Libya into Tunisia slowed drastically on Thursday and Friday, but aid workers said they worried the decline could mean that Libyan officials were harassing or blocking workers who wanted to leave the country.

headline.main: Flood of Fleeing Migrants Eases at Tunisian Border Crossing
headline.print_headline: Flood of Fleeing Migrants Eases at Tunisian Border Crossing

docs.abstract: While a dip in prices is potentially good news for the developing world, a grain expert says that tough economic times really only guarantee uncertainty for food security.
docs.snippet: While a dip in prices is potentially good news for the developing world, a grain expert says that tough economic times really only guarantee uncertainty for food security.
docs.lead_paragraph: For some Americans, fall is traditionally a season of celebrating the harvest and anticipating a groaning Thanksgiving table. Globally, it’s also the time of year for some important reports on cereal markets and food security.

headline.main: Report Sees Tight Global Cereal Markets

docs.abstract: By focusing on the consequences of climate change rather than its scientific causes, some experts suggest that a filmmaker  circumvented a divisive debate over global warming and the extent to which human activity contributes to it.
docs.snippet: By focusing on the consequences of climate change rather than its scientific causes, some experts suggest that a filmmaker  circumvented a divisive debate over global warming and the extent to which human activity contributes to it.
docs.lead_paragraph: During the shooting of his 2010 documentary “Climate Refugees,” the Irish-American filmmaker Michael Nash visited nearly 50 countries in about 18 months, interviewing politicians, scientists, health workers and victims of floods, cyclones, hurricanes and droughts.

headline.main: Film on Climate Refugees Strikes a Chord

docs.abstract: Large fruit bats lap up the running sap, sometimes fouling pots with their saliva, urine or feces; the recent outbreak has killed 35 of the 40 people known to have been infected.
docs.snippet: Large fruit bats lap up the running sap, sometimes fouling pots with their saliva, urine or feces; the recent outbreak has killed 35 of the 40 people known to have been infected.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bangladesh is suffering an outbreak of deadly Nipah virus, causing the government to adopt an unusual prevention tactic: a ban on the sale of fresh palm sap.

headline.main: Bangladesh Bans Sale of Palm Sap After an Unusually Lethal Oubreak
headline.print_headline: NIPAH VIRUS: Bangladesh Bans Sale of Palm Sap After an Unusually Lethal Oubreak
